VIII.iv.6.B.3.h
.
Establishing Proximate Cause for Non-VA Care and Unforeseeable Events
A claim for compensation under
38 U.S.C. 1151(a)(1)(B)
may be premised upon a theory of referral from VA to a non-VA medical provider or facility involving an unforeseeable event.
When a claim for compensation is predicated upon a theory of referral from VA to a non-VA medical provider or facility involving an unforeseeable event, the evidence must show that
VA medical care (the referral) proximately caused the treatment or procedure by a non-VA medical provider during which the unforeseeable event occurred,
and
the unforeseeable event caused the disability or death.
Important
:  When a claim for benefits under
38 U.S.C. 1151
associated with care in a non-VA facility by a non-VA provider is premised upon a finding that an event was not reasonably foreseeable, the two components of the chain of causation do not require an element of fault by VA.  The two components required for the chain of causation in these non-VA care scenarios are proximate cause between
both
VA medical care and the non-VA treatment,
and
the unforeseen event occurring during the non-VA treatment and the disability.
Reference
:  For more information on claims for compensation under
38 U.S.C. 1151
based on non-VA care, see
Ollis v. Shulkin
, 857 F. 3d, 1338 (2017).
